importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The rollout of the cane sugar soda began in 2025, following Trump's public demand earlier in the year.

keyTakeAways: Coca-Cola has begun rolling out a soda using cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in the United States.
The move follows a demand from President Donald Trump, who earlier this year stated that Coca-Cola had agreed to use cane sugar.

The switch is part of a broader trend in the company's shift toward healthier beverage options, including sugar-free sodas like Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which saw a 14% global volume growth in the third quarter.
Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in several other U.S. products such as Simply lemonade, Gold Peak iced tea, and Costa canned coffee.
High-fructose corn syrup has been criticized by health advocates, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who serves as Trump’s Health and Human Services Secretary.
The soda rollout is limited to 'select' cities and retailers, not nationwide yet.
Health experts have previously cautioned that sugar-filled soda—regardless of source—is not healthy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Coca-Cola has begun selling a version of its cola soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in select U.S. cities and retailers, following a public demand from President Donald Trump. The switch aligns with broader political and health advocacy, particularly from Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has criticized high-fructose corn syrup. While the soda rollout is limited, it is part of Coca-Cola’s wider strategy to expand healthier beverage options, including its successful sugar-free lines like Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and relaunched BodyArmor, and bottled water such as Smartwater.
title: Coca-Cola’s Trump-approved soda begins to roll out in the United States
